6.2 Helmholtz and Poincaré

Riemann’s ideas in turn influenced Hermann von Helmholtz, who
published several influential essays on how our knowledge of geometry
is possible. In his “On the factual [thatsächlichen]
foundations of geometry” (1866) he endeavoured to show how
only a limited number of Riemannian geometries can be constructed in
which there is a concept of rigid body motion. He argued that it is
our experience of rigid bodies that teaches us what space is like, and
in particular what distance is. He further claimed that a
2-dimensional space that admits rigid body motions would either be the
Euclidean plane or the sphere. Beltrami wrote to him to point out that
he had overlooked the possibility of non-Euclidean geometry, and
Helmholtz not only agreed, but wrote a further essay (1868) in which
he explained how it would be possible for us to have knowledge of this
geometry at an intuitive level (thus giving the lie to followers of
Kant). Many Kantians refused to be convinced, but one person that
these ideas (and Riemann's) very likely influenced was Henri
Poincaré (see Gray 2012).

As soon as Poincaré began to write his popular philosophical
essays about geometry, he made it clear that his chief concern was
with how we could rely on any geometry at all. Mathematical advances
were the basis for his reflections, but the key question was about the
epistemological status of the hypotheses on which geometry is founded.
And here he could not agree with Kant, nor Helmholtz, nor with
Riemann. He was well aware of the great range of Riemannian
geometries, and of the conclusion of Helmholtz’s speculations,
by then made rigorous in the work of Sophus Lie, that a very limited
number of geometries admitted rigid body motions. His concern in his
“On the foundations of geometry” (1898) was with
epistemology.

Poincaré argued that the mind quickly realises that it can
compensate for certain kinds of motions that it sees. If a glass comes
towards you, you can walk backwards in such a way that the glass seems
unaltered. You can do the same if it tilts or rotates. We come to
master a store of these compensating motions, and we realise that we
can follow one with another and the result will be a third
compensating motion. On this basis we come to distinguish
displacements (both our bodily displacements and displacements of
objects) from other kinds of change, i.e., alterations for which we
cannot generate compensating motions, such as the motion of the wine
in the glass as it swirls around, or a change in its colour. Most
importantly, the displacements form a mathematical structure called a
group. In this way the mind comes to form the concept of a rigid body
motion, and we elaborate a clear conceptual understanding of space on
the basis of the group of motions.

Poincaré then considered what group the group of compensating
motions could be, and found that, as Lie had proved in his study of
the Riemann-Helmholtz problem of space, there was a strictly limited
collection of such groups. Chief among them were the groups that come
from Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometry, and as abstract groups they
are different. But which one was correct?

Poincaré’s controversial view was that one could never
know, or better, than none was simply "true". Human beings, through
evolution and through our experience as infants, pick the Euclidean
group and so we say that space is Euclidean. Our bodies are quite
rigid, our motions are rigid motions, and this is decisive. Another
species, drawing on different experiences, could pick the
non-Euclidean group and so say that space was non-Euclidean. If we met
such a species, there would be no experiment that would decide the
issue.

Of course, one can make experiments using large triangles and
measuring the angles, as Lobachevskii, Riemann and others had
suggested. To maximize dimensions, assume that the sides of the
triangle are made by rays of light. Now, suppose that within the
limits of experimental error the result of the experiment is that the
angle sum of the triangle is less that \(\pi\), a result consistent
with non-Euclidean geometry but inconsistent with Euclidean geometry.
The only conclusion one can draw, said Poincaré, is that either
light rays travel along straight lines and space is non-Euclidean, or
that space is Euclidean and light rays travel along curves.

We can summarise his argument this way. Our knowledge of the geometry
of the external world is founded on our basic physical experiences,
which lead to our mental ability to deal with a group of rigid body
motions. There is a very limited store of these groups, but no
experiment can decide between them. All we can do is make a choice,
and we shall choose the simplest one. As it happens, that was the
Euclidean group, because, said Poincaré, we had found that one
of its properties not shared with the non-Euclidean group
(corresponding to the parallel postulate), was particularly simple.
But the human species had, as it were, made a choice, and that choice
was now innate in the human mind. Because of the way knowledge is
acquired and the fact that there is more than one appropriate group,
one can never know whether space is Euclidean or non-Euclidean, only
that we construct it as Euclidean.

This twist on the Kantian doctrine of the unknowability of the
Ding an sich (the thing in itself) and our confinement to the
world of appearances, was congenial to Poincaré as a working
physicist. Even though he agreed with Riemann to a large extent,
Riemann had hoped that empirical matters would guide the choice of
geometry, while Poincaré could not agree. The viewpoint just
explained is Poincaré’s philosophy of geometrical
conventionalism. But there is an important distinction to make. Notice
that this is not like the conventionality of words, but rather like
social or legal conventions (where some basic facts have to be taken
into account, see De Paz 2018). The situation is far from total
arbitrariness, since physical experience plays a decisive role and
restricts the choice; but there is no absolute determination either,
in the end a choice has to be made, and simplicity has the final
word.

He advocated conventionalism in other areas of science too, arguing
that what we call the laws of nature (Newton’s laws, e.g., the
principle of inertia) are neither empirical matters open to revision
nor absolute truths but are well established results that have been
elevated to the role of axioms in present scientific theories. They
could be challenged, but only if a whole scientific theory was being
challenged, not idly when some awkward observations were made. Faced
with a satellite that did not seem to be obeying Newton’s laws
one should, said Poincaré, consider some as-yet unnoticed force
at work and not seek to re-write Newton. But a new theory can be
proposed, based on different assumptions that rewrite a law of nature,
because these laws are not eternal truths—we could never know
such things. And if a new law were to be proposed, simplicity and not
only empirical fit will be taken into account as one chooses between
the new and the old.

The crucial distinction here is that scientific conventionalism
operates at a high level. The choices are made consciously and
intellectually, the debate is only open to people with a considerable
amount of specialised education. On the other hand, the choice of
Euclidean geometry operates in the mind before it is capable of any
kind of formal instruction; without some geometric framework,
the unfortunate subject would be incapable of any knowledge of the
external world.
